articles.headline: Time Runs Out for an Afghan Held by the U.S.
articles.snippet: The fate of the first detainee to die of natural causes at Guantánamo Bay reveals the problems of military tribunals, Afghans say.
articles.abstract: The fate of the first detainee to die of natural causes at Guantánamo Bay reveals the problems of military tribunals, Afghans say.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Abdul Razzaq Hekmati was regarded here as a war hero, famous for his resistance to the Russian occupation in the 1980s and later for a daring prison break he organized for three opponents of the Taliban government in 1999.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Andy Worthington

articles.headline: A Trader’s Secrets, a Bank’s Missteps
articles.snippet: Société Générale encouraged a culture of risk,  enabling  rogue trader Jérôme Kerviel’s activities to go undetected, according to bank officials.
articles.abstract: Société Générale encouraged a culture of risk,  enabling  rogue trader Jérôme Kerviel’s activities to go undetected, according to bank officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  The first e-mail message arrived in Société Générale’s offices on Nov. 7. The surveillance office at Eurex, one of Europe’s biggest exchanges, alerted a compliance officer at the bank that for seven months a trader named Jérôme Kerviel had engaged in not just one but “several transactions” that had raised red flags.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Katrin Bennhold

articles.headline: Europe’s Central Banker Engineers His Economics
articles.snippet: Jean-Claude Trichet, president of the European Central Bank, is standing resolute about inflation, but he is watching the American economy closely.
articles.abstract: Jean-Claude Trichet, president of the European Central Bank, is standing resolute about inflation, but he is watching the American economy closely.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT  The day after the Federal Reserve’s emergency interest rate cut two weeks ago, Jean-Claude Trichet went before the European Parliament to deliver perhaps the most eagerly awaited speech of his four years as president of the European Central Bank.

articles.headline: Google and Microsoft Take Up Battle Stations
articles.snippet: With Microsoft hoping to buy Yahoo, Google has begun to lay the groundwork to try to delay or derail any deal.
articles.abstract: With Microsoft hoping to buy Yahoo, Google has begun to lay the groundwork to try to delay or derail any deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  It could be payback time.
articles.byline: By Stephen Labaton and Miguel Helft

articles.headline: Economy Fitful, Americans Start to Pay as They Go
articles.snippet: Analysts say a shift toward thrift could have huge implications for an economy driven largely by consumer spending.
articles.abstract: Analysts say a shift toward thrift could have huge implications for an economy driven largely by consumer spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than half a century, Americans have proved staggeringly resourceful at finding new ways to spend money.

articles.headline: Utilities Turn From Coal to Gas, Raising Risk of Price Increase
articles.snippet: Some experts fear that a boom in gas demand for electricity generation will send prices even higher.
articles.abstract: Some experts fear that a boom in gas demand for electricity generation will send prices even higher.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Stymied in their plans to build coal-burning power plants, American utilities are turning to natural gas to meet expected growth in demand, risking a new upward spiral in the price of that fuel.

articles.headline: As 24 States Vote, a Grab for Delegates, and an Edge
articles.snippet: A total of 3,156 delegates will be allocated under arcane rules on what could be the most significant day yet in the 2008 campaign.
articles.abstract: A total of 3,156 delegates will be allocated under arcane rules on what could be the most significant day yet in the 2008 campaign.

articles.headline: The Art of Giving a Bear Hug
articles.snippet: In a letter outlining Microsoft’s  hopes to Yahoo C.E.O. Jerry Yang, Microsoft C.E.O. Steven Ballmer followed a storied tradition on Wall Street: the bear hug letter.
articles.abstract: In a letter outlining Microsoft’s  hopes to Yahoo C.E.O. Jerry Yang, Microsoft C.E.O. Steven Ballmer followed a storied tradition on Wall Street: the bear hug letter.
articles.lead_paragraph: Steven Ballmer was laying it on thick.
